Accessibility.blurb: Accessibility is an important part of computer science, as we can create inclusive and usable technologies for everyone to enjoy. Aspects of accessible design are used in many other fields such as software engineering and assistive technology.

instructors.name: Vinitha Gadiraju
instructors.bio: My research centers on building collaborative, equitable tools for people with disabilities, particularly in the context of learning and education.

Algorithms.blurb: An algorithm is a set of step-by-step instructions. Popular examples include sorting algorithms, search algorithms, graph traversal algorithms, and data compressio algorithms. The study of algorithms teaches you how to design and implement algorithms, and how to prove properties such as correctness or efficiency.

instructors.name: Christin Bassem
instructors.bio: My broad research interests are in mechanism and algorithm design for dynamic distributed systems, including crowd networks, mobile ad-hoc networks, and transport networks.

instructors.name: Brian Brubach
instructors.bio: I have broad research interests in algorithms and theoretical computer science motivated by a range of social good applications.

instructors.name: Brian Tjaden
instructors.bio: My work focuses on the design, analysis, and implementation of algorithms with applications in genomics and molecular biology.

opportunities.title: AlgoWiki
opportunities.about: A team at MIT FutureTech that works on documenting algorithms throughout history.

Compilers.blurb: A compiler is a specialized software that translates human-readable source code (such as Python or Java) into a lower-level language (such as binary instruction) that a computer's processor can execute.

Computability & Complexity Theory.blurb: Complexity Theory is the study of identifying and classifying difficult problems. One can measure the difficulty of a problem through the time and computational power needed to solve it.

Computer Architecture.blurb: Computer architecture is the design and implementation of low level hardware components (such as CPU and memory), and how they work together to execute programs and act as a bridge between instructions and software.

instructors.name: Alexa Vanhattum
instructors.bio: I use lightweight formal methods to improve the reliability and efficiency of low-level computer systems.

instructors.name: Peter Mawhorter
instructors.bio: I'm especially interested in teaching programming basics to scientists who need them for their experiments, and to humanists who want to sharpen their understanding of our increasingly code-driven world.

Computer Graphics.blurb: Computer graphics is the art and science of creating images and art with the aid of computers. Popuplar applications include digital photography, film, displays like the one you would see on a cell phone, and video games!

instructors.name: Scott Anderson
instructors.bio: Professor Anderson's teaching interests include web application programming, including databases, web frameworks, and computer graphics

opportunities.title: SIGGRAPH
opportunities.about: A research conference all about computer graphics, organized by ACM.

instructors.name: Eni Mustafaraj
instructors.bio: I am a computational data scientist who studies the online information environment shaped by the interactions of algorithms, humans, and organizations.

instructors.name: Jordan Tynes
instructors.bio: My work at Wellesley College and beyond focuses on the creation and study of immersive and interactive learning experiences.

opportunities.title: Wellesley Game Dev Club
opportunities.about: 'Community of students interested in computer science, animation, and game design.'

instructors.name: Catherine Delcourt
instructors.bio: My research interests are varied in the areas of Human-Computer Interaction and Social Computing.

instructors.name: Vinitha Gadiraju
instructors.bio: I approach my work through prototyping and qualitative research methods, including ethnography, co-design, user evaluation, interviews, and diary studies.

instructors.name: Orit Shaer
instructors.bio: Her research focuses on novel human-computer interaction for the future of work and learning, including human-AI collaboration, tangible and embodied interaction, and mixed-reality interfaces.

opportunities.title: HCI Lab
opportunities.about: Students can get involved in HCI research projects through the HCI lab on campus.

instructors.name: Carolyn Anderson
instructors.bio: In order to develop language technology that interacts with us in a natural way, we need to develop models that can adjust their language based on users' situations and knowledge states.

instructors.name: Yaniv Yacoby
instructors.bio: My research focuses on developing new machine learning methods to advance the understanding, prediction, and prevention of suicide and related behaviors.

courses.course_name: Probablistic Foundations of Predictive Machine Learning

opportunities.title: MOGU Lab
opportunities.about: 'Machine Learning (ML) laboratory at Wellesley College, focused on enabling effective and responsible uses of expressive (deep) ML models in safety-critical domains like precision healthcare.'

instructors.name: Carolyn Anderson
instructors.bio: I use computational, experimental, and symbolic methods to understand meaning in natural language.

instructors.name: Christin Bassem
instructors.bio: My broad research interests are in mechanism and algorithm design for dynamic distributed systems, including crowd networks, mobile ad-hoc networks, and transport networks.

instructors.name: Alexa Vanhattum
instructors.bio: My interests span programming languages and computer systems.

instructors.name: Franklyn Turbak
instructors.bio: My passion is the study of programs and programming languages, which is at the heart of both my teaching and research.

instructors.name: Scott Anderson
instructors.bio: Professor Anderson's teaching interests include web application programming, including databases, web frameworks, and computer graphics.

instructors.name: Scott Anderson
instructors.bio: Professor Anderson's teaching interests include web application programming, including databases, web frameworks, and computer graphics.

opportunities.title: UpSkill (Software Development Lifecycle)
opportunities.about: A wintersession program for Wellesley students to learn about Github and collaborate on a project.
